title: How we got the $15.57b shot of Anthony Pratt
text:
Matthew Drummond AFR Magazine editor May 30, 2019 — 5.00pm Share

If a picture is worth a thousand words, how do you take a cover shot of a man worth $15.57 billion?

That was the challenge for The Australian Financial Review Magazine creative director Tim Beor, art director Sam Bennett and photographer Alina Gozin'a, who wanted to show Australia's richest man in a different light for the cover of the 2019 Financial Review Rich List.

For Gozin'a, a different light meant figuring out the precise location to park Pratt's private jet so that the dawn sun would burst across the fuselage at the exact moment that Pratt would be available for his photograph.

"We were told we only had 15 minutes with him," said Gozin'a, who has shot regularly for AFR Magazine, including portraits of Judith Neilson, Terry Snow, Frank Lowy and his sons and five notable women including Gretel Packer who've donated to Sydney Modern. "We couldn't have made it work without receiving so much help from Anthony Pratt's team. They were phenomenal."

In researching her feature on Pratt for AFR Magazine, senior writer Jemima Whyte had heard that Pratt's son Leon recently asked to attend a Visy board meeting for this ninth birthday. That led to her focusing on what Anthony had learnt about business from his late father Richard, and what he was, in turn, teaching his children.

Anthony Pratt, happily obliging our photographer's request to make a delivery on his Bombardier. Alina Gozin'a

When the Pratt family politely declined the request to photograph Anthony with his children, AFR Magazine's creative team turned to iconic shots of jets for inspiration. Pratt obliged to the request to pose with his Bombadier Global Express and had envisaged a quick photo shoot that would show off the tail of his jet, which features the logo of his US box manufacturer, Pratt Industries.

Unfortunately magazine covers are rarely simple.

The day before the shoot Gozin'a spent four hours at Melbourne's Essendon airport testing the light, angles and different camera lenses to create the exact effect she was after. As requested, staff at one of Pratt's factories provided pallets of boxes, a forklift and a choice of drivers while Gozin'a brought in two assistants, a smoke machine, screens, tripods and cameras.
description: Cover shoots are never easy. This one was especially out of the box.
